intro: Cerastium edmondstonii, commonly known as Edmondston's mouse-ear, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its dense clusters of small, white flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant has hairy, spoon-shaped leaves and forms a mat-like growth habit, often found in rocky or sandy soils. It is adapted to arid environments and is often used in rock gardens or as a ground cover. Its botanical features make it a distinctive and ecologically important species in its native habitat.
